posts.name:
Frank Eggink
Frank Eggink
posts.content:
As many of you know, I am a strong advocate for self-management and bossless organisations. 

There are numerous success stories about companies operating this way.

However, to explore the other side, I started reading 𝐖𝐡𝐲 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐌𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫: 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐥𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐁𝐨𝐬𝐬𝐥𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐧𝐲.

I'm nearly halfway through and find it incredibly thought-provoking. Thank you,for recommending me this book!

posts.name:
Vikas Chawla
Vikas Chawla
posts.content:
PUMA Group's viral 'mistake' turned out to be their most brilliant marketing move of 2025. Here's the fascinating strategy behind it.

I was fascinated by PUMA's recent brand campaign that had everyone talking - but for reasons they didn't expect.

You might have noticed PUMA's logo mysteriously transforming to 'PVMA' across their social media platforms. The internet did what it does best:
created memes, sparked debates, and drove organic conversations.

What looked like a design error was actually PUMA's clever strategy to announceas their brand ambassador.

Bold strategies like these have helped PUMA achieve revenues of over 3000 crores in India—more than double that of Nike, which stands at 1200 crores.
3 marketing lessons from PUMA's viral campaign:

 The power of subtle changes - Sometimes the smallest tweak (literally one letter!) can create the biggest impact. The beauty was in its simplicity.

 Understanding viral mechanics - PUMA knew that apparent 'mistakes' by big brands get massive attention. They leveraged this behavior brilliantly.

 Perfect brand-ambassador integration - Instead of just another celebrity announcement, they wove PV Sindhu's identity into their own brand identity.

In my 20 years of marketing, I've seen countless brand ambassador announcements.
Most follow the same template: press release → photoshoot → social post. What made this campaign brilliant was how it turned the formula on its head and let curiosity drive engagement.

When you first saw the 'PVMA' logo, did you think it was a mistake or did you catch onto the strategy?

comments.commentText: I really really loved the mastermind behind this super marketing strategy. This looks like a new trend among the trends of marketing world.
For those with sharing gyaan for changing brand image etc etc.. do t u guys know this stunt is just to announce her as Ambassador., it not gonna change forever!

posts.name:
Dr. Birendra Singh
Dr. Birendra Singh
posts.content:
Main reasons of employee leaving job based on my experience,

• Lack of growth opportunities, working in same role
• Overworking with out support of Seniors
• Achievements are unnoticed, and partiality in rewards
• Trust, if broken from both the sides
• Uncompetitive compensation
• Leadership disconnect
• Promotion to non-performers
• Feeling undervalued compared to industry peers
• When personal and organizational values clash

Mental resignation happens much before actual resignation?

comments.commentText:
Great perspective! 

One of the main reasons people leave their jobs is that they stop feeling valued or connected to the organization. Beyond what you have already mentioned, I think a lack of transparent communication plays a big role. When employees don’t understand how their work contributes to the bigger picture, they lose motivation.

Another issue is that companies often focus more on short-term results rather than long-term employee engagement. Recognizing achievements, providing clear growth paths, and offering regular feedback are simple yet effective ways to keep employees engaged.

I also believe companies need to create an environment where employees feel heard. Leaders should encourage open discussions about challenges and provide consistent support not just during appraisals but throughout the year. :)

Finally, fostering a sense of belonging through shared values and strong leadership can make a big difference. When employees feel connected to the organization’s mission and see leadership living those values, they’re less likely to look elsewhere.

Harsh Chaudhary well defined path for others you don't feel they are also employees once in the same position now ignoring down the line. If employees keep hoping and these Managers and their mind set too, there is no end to the data and industry knowledge retention or loyalty

Well said sir but where is the solution,who is taking note of it.

posts.name:
Mike Connolly
Mike Connolly
posts.content:
Doing some work on a flight. The guy next to me is too. We started talking.

Turns out he's writing annual reviews for his direct reports. Cool - good use of plane time.

Until I saw he's using ChatGTP to write his reviews. Not just to fine tune the reviews - literally just putting in a simple prompt and copy/pasting the output.

The biggest responsibility you have as a leader is to give actionable feedback to your team (realtime, not just in reviews).

To treat annual reviews with such a lazy approach is inexcusable.

(He's also an armrest hog  )

comments.commentText: I’m sure it’s better than he would be capable of himself

posts.name:
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
posts.content:
How to Document a Winning Sales Call
 
Most salespeople think the call ends when they hang up. But the real magic happens in the debrief. Here’s how I break it down into a system that builds confidence, clarity, and consistent results:

<<<1. Call Structure Check>>>
--> Did I create rapport?
--> Did I clearly state the goal of the call?
--> Did I confidently ask for the sale/next step?

<<<2. Objection Analysis>>>
--> What objections stumped me today?
--> Which objections used to feel easy but caught me off guard this time?

<<3. Highlight Reel>>
--> What’s ONE THING I nailed during this call that I want to replicate next time?

This simple reflection process turns every sales call—whether a win or a loss—into an opportunity to improve.

 What’s YOUR favorite way to debrief after a call? Let’s share and grow together.

comments.commentText: How does this work in real life? Start with the basics: ask yourself if you maintained control of the call. If you skipped that part, the rest won’t matter.

posts.name:
Travis Simat
Travis Simat
posts.content:
Let's talk about the "call me in 6 months" objection. 

We all know sales is about timing, but don't let this brush-off crush you.

Here is one example on how I handle it.

"I appreciate your timeline, but it seems like we have a serious use case here. You mentioned [specific pain points].
If I may, I would like to suggest we have a conversation now to demonstrate how we can address [problem 1] and [problem 2] right now.
This way, we can determine if this solution will truly be worth both our time in 6 months.
Does that sound fair?"

It's about creating urgency without being pushy.

Your job is to help them solve problems. Don't let a little timeline get in the way of that.
